questiontext.text: Which elements are necessary to describe the security dilemma?

answer.text: Anarchy
A balance of power
Multipolarity
An assessment of the counterpart as aggressive or peaceful
An alliance partner
A decision how to response: arming or not

questiontext.text: What is the difference between arms control and disarmament?

answer.text: Arms control thinks conflict is endemic, disarmament thinks conflict  results from armament
Arms control aims at constraining technology, disarmament aims at constraining numbers
Arms control may promote higher levels of armament if that makes the situation more stable. Disarmament always aims at reductions
Arms control pursues stability, disarmament pursues elimination

questiontext.text: What are the three types of stability at which arms control aims?

answer.text: Political stability
Crisis stability
Stability of the balance of power
Strategic stability
Arms race stability

questiontext.text: What are the differences of conventional weapons and weapons of mass destruction?

answer.text: Conventional weapons are delivered by tank, artillery and aircraft. Weapons of mass destruction by missiles and rockets.
Conventional weapons are used on the battlefield, and against soldiers.  Weapons of mass destruction  against cities and civilians.
Conventional weapons kill by kinetic impact or chemical explosions, WMD by other chemical reactions, viruses, bacteria, toxins, radiation and nuclear fission and fusion.

questiontext.text: What are the three primary goals of arms control?

answer.text: Stability
Reduced numbers of weapons
Enhancing military strength
Reduced costs
Damage limitation in war

questiontext.text: What is meant by the term ’control unit’?

answer.text: The organization which is charged with verifying the agreement
The technical instrument by which inspectors measure compliance of the parties with their undertakings
The part or characteristic of the weapons system that is subject to quantitative and/or qualitative constraints

questiontext.text: Which of the following arms control measures are part of the “quantitative approach”?

answer.text: Controlled growth
Deployment constraints
Information exchange
Reduction
Elimination

questiontext.text: What is the task of the review conference of a treaty?

answer.text: Assess the degree of implementation of a treaty by its parties
Impose sanctions on parties that have breached their undertakings
Distribute the budget to help poor parties with capacity building
Agree on proposals to improve the working of the treaty and the practices of the members

questiontext.text: Which of the following statements are true?

answer.text: The UN Security Council could not agree to impose sanctions on Iran despite Iran’s violation of its untertakings under the NPT.
Libya and South Africa stopped their WMD programs because of sanctions unrelated to its WMD policies.

Military force has never be useful against WMD programs.
There have been UN Security Council sanctions against North Korea for many years, but they had no influence on the country’s WMD policy.

questiontext.text: Decision on which of the following actions is within the authority of the UN General Assembly?

answer.text: Imposing sanctions  on countries which breach their legal agreement.
Condemning certain forms of armament by resolution.
Constituting a negotiation forum for a new disarmament treaty.
Sending inspectors to verify the illegal use of chemical weapons.

questiontext.text: What are the main characteristics of human security?

answer.text: Human security concentrates on individual physical security including aspects of economic, food, health and environmental security
Human security means securing the supply of food to people in distress (e.g. after earthquakes
Human security adds the dimension of development to collective security
Human security entitles individuals to take up arms against the state

questiontext.text: What are the main points of critique to the statist definition of arms control from a gender perspective?

answer.text: Mainstream statist arms control fails to identify and criticize the structural power relations that sustain militarism and war, notably a masculine “gun cultures”. It’s a therapy for symptoms, not for roots.
Women should always be chairs of arms control negotiations and of the UN Office for disarmament.
As part of gender equality, men and women should be equally involved in matters of arms control.

questiontext.text: Which arms control agreements were the main products of the period between World War I and World War II?

answer.text: The prohibition of dum-dum bullets
The Geneva Protocol prohibiting the use of chemical and biological weapons
The Biological Weapons Convention
The Washington Treaties trying to establish a balance among the major powers’ navies

questiontext.text: Which major crisis proved the decisive trigger for nuclear arms control among the US and the Soviet Union?

answer.text: The Korean War, because it led to the first threat of nuclear weapons against communist countries (North Korea and China)
The Suez Crisis, because it led to the threat of nuclear weapons by Moscow against the UK and France
The Berlin Crises of 1958 and 1961, because it threatened an immediate military confrontation between NATO and the Warshaw Pact
The Cuban missile crisis, because it brought the superpowers to the brink of a nuclear war and showed the necessity of mutual compromise

questiontext.text: In nuclear arms control, is it better to control the number of warheads or the number of missiles?

answer.text: Missiles, because they are bigger objects and thus can be better verified
Warheads, because otherwise parties will be tempted to put more warheads on missiles and to  build bigger missiles to have more warheads
Missiles, because the fewer missiles exist, the better chances missile defense will have

Warheads, because the more warheads are put on a single missile, the more warheads can be fired at a single missile silo, the easier it is to destroy the enemy’s nuclear capabilities in a first strike and the more instable the situation becomes

questiontext.text: Are missile defenses good or bad for arms control?

answer.text: good, because countries that can protect themselves will feel more secure and not be tempted to strike first because of the “use or loose” problem
bad, because states could decide to strike first because they trust that their missile defense could deal with the few surviving missiles of the enemy
bad, because states which are behind in missile defense will  build up their offensive forces and try other countermeasures like electronic warfare
good, because states will invest in defensive capabilities and there will be less ressources left for  their offensive forces

questiontext.text: Which of the following arms control agreements are regional?

answer.text: The Nuclear Non-Proliferation Treaty
The Australian Group
Nuclear weapon free zones
The START Treaties

questiontext.text: Which of the following agreements are global?

answer.text: The Chemical Weapons Convention
The CFE Treaty
The Ottawa Convention prohibiting anti-personal mines
The INF Treaty

questiontext.text: Which of the following statements on export control arrangements like the Nuclear Suppliers Group or the Australia Group are true?

answer.text: They are meant to avoid a “race to the bottom” among concerning conditions under which items related to weapons of mass destruction or weapons are exported.
They serve to preserve the technological oligopoly of rich countries.
They help exporters to fulfill their obligations from non-proliferation and disarmament treaties.
They serve to enhance exporters’ knowledge on ongoing illegal purchasing activities through information exchange.

questiontext.text: What can a party to a multilateral arms control treaty like the CWC or the NPT legally do when it suspects another party to breach its obligations?

answer.text: Send immetiately national inspectors to the suspected state to check what is going on
Seek clarification by bilateral diplomacy
Start preemptive attack to destroy the suspected sites
Require the verifying international agency to inquire the case
Provide related intelligence information to the verifying international agency

questiontext.text: Can arms control effectively change the political situations among states?

answer.text: No, it can’t. When political relations are bad, there will be no arms control. When political relations are good, arms control is at best a nice symbol but does not influence relations.
Yes, arms control can stabilize the military rivalry among states and thus prevent dangerous crises
Yes, arms control can even help transform the relations by building up trust and building down mutual fears.

questiontext.text: Can arms control which was “invented” in the bipolar Cold War, be useful today?

answer.text: Yes, it is urgently needed to manage the dangers of a multipolar nuclear arms race between the major powers (US, China, Russia, India)
No, it was dependent on the specific circumstances of bipolarity and is thus obsolete
Yes, the multilateral treaties to dismantle and/or prevent the spread of weapons of mass destruction remain pillars of world stability in a more multipolar system as well

questiontext.text: What is the meaning of “opportunity cost of armament” concerning the relationship between disarmament and development?

answer.text: Financial ressources invested in armament by developed countries are not available for development aid
Financial ressources expended by developing countries for  armament by developing countries are not available for development projects (education, health, infrastructure etc.)
The opportunity for arms producing companies to sell weapons for the defense of developing countries

questiontext.text: What is the meaning of the acronym “DDR” in  peacekeeping missions?

answer.text: Democratization, Disarmament, Rehabilitation
Disengagement, De-escalation, Regulation
Disarmament, De-mobilization, Re-integration

questiontext.text: How can humanitarian arms control be defined?

answer.text: Humanitarian arms control concentrates on the protection of civilians and the rehabilitation of victims as an integrated part of arms control
Humanitarian arms control seeks to prohibit weapons and trade in weapons that are most likely to hurt the civilian population
Humanitarian arms control promotes the end of arming police with deadly weapons
Humanitarian arms control seeks to prevent the potential ecological hazards of an nuclear arms race

questiontext.text: Which institution decides about EU strategies for the non-proliferation of nuclear weapons?

answer.text: The EU Council
The President of the EU Commission
The European Atomic Community (EURATOM)

questiontext.text: Which institutions are involved in implementing EU non-proliferation and disarmament policy?

answer.text: The High Representative for Foreign and Security Policy
The European External Action Service (EEAS)
The European Central Bank
The Special Envoy for Disarmament and Non-proliferation

questiontext.text: Which are preferred instruments of EU non-proliferation policy?

answer.text: Military pressure on parties which do not engage sufficiently in non-proliferation
Multilateral negotiations
Export controls
Buying off dangerous materials and technologies in developing countries by enhanced development aid
